an8.74:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Nādika in the brick house.
an8.74:1.2: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
an8.74:1.3: “Mendicants, when mindfulness of death is developed and cultivated it’s very fruitful and beneficial. It culminates in the deathless and ends with the deathless.
an8.74:2.1: And how is mindfulness of death developed and cultivated to be very fruitful and beneficial, to culminate in the deathless and end with the deathless?
an8.74:2.2: As day passes by and night draws close, a mendicant reflects:
an8.74:2.4: A snake might bite me, or a scorpion or centipede might sting me.
an8.74:2.5: And if I died from that it would stop my practice.
an8.74:2.6: Or I might stumble off a cliff, or get food poisoning, or suffer a disturbance of bile, phlegm, or piercing winds. Or I might be attacked by humans or non-humans.
an8.74:2.7: And if I died from that it would stop my practice.’
an8.74:2.9: ‘Are there any bad, unskillful qualities that I haven’t given up, which might be an obstacle to me if I die tonight?’
an8.74:3.1: Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
an8.74:3.2: there are such bad, unskillful qualities. Then in order to give them up they should apply outstanding enthusiasm, effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness.
an8.74:4.1: Suppose your clothes or head were on fire. In order to extinguish it, you’d apply intense enthusiasm, effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness.
an8.74:4.2: In the same way, in order to give up those bad, unskillful qualities, that mendicant should apply outstanding enthusiasm …
an8.74:5.1: But suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
an8.74:5.2: there are no such bad, unskillful qualities. Then that mendicant should meditate with rapture and joy, training day and night in skillful qualities.
an8.74:6.1: Or else, as night passes by and day draws close, a mendicant reflects:
an8.74:6.3: A snake might bite me, or a scorpion or centipede might sting me.
an8.74:6.4: And if I died from that it would stop my practice.
an8.74:6.5: Or I might stumble off a cliff, or get food poisoning, or suffer a disturbance of bile, phlegm, or piercing winds. Or I might be attacked by humans or non-humans.
an8.74:6.6: And if I died from that it would stop my practice.’
an8.74:6.8: ‘Are there any bad, unskillful qualities that I haven’t given up, which might be an obstacle to me if I die today?’
an8.74:7.1: Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
an8.74:7.2: there are such bad, unskillful qualities. Then in order to give them up they should apply outstanding enthusiasm, effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness.
an8.74:8.1: Suppose your clothes or head were on fire. In order to extinguish it, you’d apply intense enthusiasm, effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness.
an8.74:8.2: In the same way, in order to give up those bad, unskillful qualities, that mendicant should apply outstanding enthusiasm …
an8.74:9.1: But suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
an8.74:9.2: there are no such bad, unskillful qualities. Then that mendicant should meditate with rapture and joy, training day and night in skillful qualities.
an8.74:9.3: Mindfulness of death, when developed and cultivated in this way, is very fruitful and beneficial. It culminates in the deathless and ends with the deathless.”
